div.head: Introduction
div.p: Tropical waters are oligotrophic and therefore known as 'deserts' of the sea, but some marine invertebrates such as scleractinian corals and giant clams can flourish in such oligotrophic environment. Specifically, giant clams (Genus: Tridacna or Hippopus) are inhabitants of the Indo-Pacific reef ecosystems. They can grow rapidly despite the shortage of nutrients and are the largest of all bivalves because they live in mutualistic association with Symbiodiniaceae dinoflagellates of genera Symbiodinium, Cladocopium, Durusdinium and Gerakladium (Hernawan, 2008;Weber, 2009;DeBoer et al., 2012;Ikeda et al., 2017;Lim et al., 2019;Pochon et al., 2019;Guibert et al., 2020). In giant clams, symbiotic dinoflagellates reside extracellularly in a branched tubular system that originates from the host's digestive tract (Norton et al., 1992). The tertiary tubules containing the majority of symbionts are located predominantly in the colorful and extensible outer mantle that contains pigments and iridophores (Norton et al., 1992). As the symbionts have no access to the ambient seawater, the host needs to supply them with nutrients such as inorganic carbon (C i ), nitrogen, and phosphorus. During illumination, photosynthesizing dinoflagellates donate as much as 95% of the photosynthates to the clam host in order to fulfil its energy and nutrition requirements (Klumpp and Griffiths, 1994). As a result, the host can maintain high growth rate and conduct light-enhanced shell formation in nutrient poor tropical waters (Ip et al., 2017;Rossbach et al., 2019). Unlike non-symbiotic bivalve mollusks, shell formation in giant clams is enhanced by light because the growth rate of the host is the highest while receiving organic nutrients from its photosynthesizing symbionts.

Light-enhanced shell formation involves the increased deposition of CaCO 3 (Ca 2+ + HCO 3 − ⇔ CaCO 3 + H + ) from the extrapallial fluid onto the inside surface of the shell valve during illumination. Hence, giant clams need to increase the uptake of Ca 2+ from the external seawater during illumination to support light-enhanced shell formation, and there are indications that Ca 2+ uptake occurs through the ctenidium (Cao-Pham et al., 2019). Each giant clam consists of two ctenidia and each ctenidium comprises two demibranches. The ctenidium is comb-shaped, and consists of many protruding filaments and numerous internal tertiary water channels. Together, the filaments and water channels increase the surface area of the ctenidium tremendously so that it can function effectively in many physiological processes, including gaseous exchange, nutrient uptake, waste excretion and acid-base balance. The ctenidium of the fluted giant clam, Tridacna squamosa, participates in many light-enhanced processes (Ip et al., 2015;. It takes part in the absorption of Ca 2+ (voltage-gated calcium channel subunit alpha 1, CACNA1; Cao-Pham et al., 2019), C i (dual domain carbonic anhydrase; Koh et al., 2018), urea (urea active transporter or DUR3; Chan et al., 2018), glucose (sodium/glucose cotransporter 1 or SGLT1; Chan et al., 2019), NO 3 − (H + :2NO 3 − cotransporter or SIALIN;Ip et al., 2020), and inorganic phosphate (sodium-dependent phosphate transport protein 2a or NPT2a; Chan et al., 2020a; sodium-dependent phosphate transporter protein 1; . It is involved in the assimilation of ammonia (glutamine synthetase; Hiong et al., 2017a) and the excretion of H + (Na + /H + exchanger 3 or NHE3; Hiong et al., 2017b; vacuolar-type H + -ATPase subunit A; Ip et al., 2018). It can also participate in light-suppressed ammonia excretion (ammonium transporter 1; Boo et al., 2018). Notably, the gene and/or protein expression levels of the above-mentioned transporters and enzymes are lightdependent in the ctenidium of T. squamosa. Concerning Ca 2+ absorption, the ctenidium of T. squamosa expresses a homolog of CACNA1, which is the pore-forming subunit of the L-type voltage-gated Ca 2+ channel (VGCC). CACNA1 is localized in the apical membrane of epithelial cells covering the filaments or lining the tertiary water channels (Cao-Pham et al., 2019). The protein abundance of CACNA1 increases significantly in the ctenidium of T. squamosa during light exposure to augment exogenous Ca 2+ uptake. In addition, the ctenidium of T. squamosa expresses a homolog of sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca 2+ -ATPase (SERCA-like), and illumination also significantly enhances its protein expression level (Chan et al., 2020b). Hence, the Ca 2+ absorbed through VGCC into the ctenidial epithelial cells can be sequestered by SERCA-like into the endoplasmic reticulum and traverse the cell interior without perturbing cytosolic [Ca 2+ ] homeostasis. As the free [Ca 2+ ] in the cytosol is about 10,000-fold lower than that (2.1-2.6 mM) in the extracellular fluid (Gilad et al., 2013;Carafoli and Krebs, 2016), Ca 2+ cannot exit cells passively by diffusion and must be actively transported across the basolateral membrane of the epithelial cells into the hemolymph against a large [Ca 2+ ] gradient. To date, the identity of this active Ca 2+ transporter in the basolateral membrane of the ctenidium of T. squamosa remains elusive.

In general, two types of Ca 2+ transporter can facilitate the extrusion of Ca 2+ across the plasma membrane: plasma membrane Ca 2+ -ATPase (PMCA) and Na + /Ca 2+ exchanger (NCX). PMCA has a high Ca 2+ affinity but low Ca 2+ transport capacity, and it may have a housekeeping role in maintaining cytosolic [Ca 2+ ] (Brini and Carafoli, 2011). In comparison, NCX may play a dynamic role of counteracting large potential variations in cytosolic [Ca 2+ ] as it has low Ca 2+ affinity for Ca 2+ but high capacity for its transport (Brini and Carafoli, 2011). Consequently, PMCA represents only a minute portion of proteins (<0.1%) in the plasma membrane (Brini and Carafoli, 2011). NCX typically transports one Ca 2+ out of the cell in exchange for the import of three Na + ions. It can operate in a bidirectional fashion, depending on the electrochemical gradients of Ca 2+ and Na + . There are three isoforms of NCX (NCX1, NCX2, and NCX3; Philipson et al., 1988;Nicoll et al., 1996). They can have specialized physiological functions, which include calcification in osteoblast (Stains and Gay, 1998;Akisaka et al., 1988;Sosnoski and Gay, 2008) and ameloblast (Okumura et al., 2010), transepithelial Ca 2+ transport across kidney and intestine, Ca 2+ removal from lens, muscle contractility, and neurotransmitter release (Blaustein and Lederer, 1999;Hoenderop et al., 2005).

As NCX1 is widely expressed in various epithelial cells (Liao et al., 2012), this study aimed to clone and sequence NCX1 from the ctenidium of T. squamosa. Then, an anti-NCX1 polyclonal antibody was custommade for the localization of NCX1 in the ctenidium by immunofluorescence microscopy. The hypothesis tested was that NCX1 would have a basal localization in the ctenidial epithelial cells. In addition, the transcript level and protein abundance of NCX1/NCX1 were determined by quantitative real time-PCR (qPCR) and Western blotting, respectively, to test the hypothesis that they could be upregulated in the ctenidium of individuals exposed to light as compared with those exposed to darkness. If occurred, the active extrusion of Ca 2+ through NCX1 driven by the influx of Na + down its electrochemical potential gradient would increase the intracellular [Na + ]. As the intracellular Na + homeostasis is known to be maintained by Na + /K + -ATPase (NKA; Blanco and Mercer, 1998), efforts were made to determine whether illumination would also affect the expression level of NKA α-subunit (NKAα) in the ctenidium of T. squamosa. NKA comprises three types of subunits (α, β, and γ), and each subunit has its isoforms. There are at least one αand one β-subunit in a functional NKA (Jorgensen et al., 2003), with NKAα (110-120 kDa) containing the ATP binding site and the catalytic domains for the binding and transporting of Na + and K + (Blanco and Mercer, 1998). Preliminary results obtained in this study revealed that the NKAα amino acid sequence obtained from the ctenidium of T. squamosa was identical to that obtained from the inner mantle as reported by Boo et al. (2017). Hence, we adopted the qPCR primer set and the anti-NKAα antibody designed by Boo et al. (2017) based on NKAα of the inner mantle to determine the transcript and protein expression levels of NKAα/NKAα in the ctenidium of individuals of T. squamosa exposed to light or darkness. The anti-NKAα antibody was also used to determine the subcellular localization of NKAα in the ctenidium by immunofluorescence microscopy. It was hypothesized that NKAα had a basolateral localization and its expression level would be upregulated in the ctenidium during light exposure. Results obtained were expected to provide a deeper understanding on the molecular mechanisms involved in light-enhanced Ca 2+ absorption through the gills of T. squamosa apropos of light-enhanced shell formation.

div.head: Materials and methods
Animals, experimental conditions, and tissue collection
div.p: Individuals of T. squamosa (520 ± 180 g with shells; n = 26) were purchased from Xanh Tuoi Tropical Fish Ltd. in Vietnam. They were acclimated in three glass tanks (L90 cm x W62 cm x H60 cm) under a 12 h light:12 h dark regime for one month before experimentation. Each tank contained 350 L of recirculating seawater and 8 or 9 clams. The water conditions were as follows: salinity, 30-32; temperature, ~26 • C; pH, 8.1-8.3; hardness, 143-179 ppm; calcium, 380-420 ppm; phosphate, <0.25 ppm; nitrate, 0 ppm; nitrite, 0 ppm, total ammonia, <0.25 ppm. The underwater light intensity (PPFD) at the level of the clam was ~120 μmol m − 2 s − 1 . Institutional approval was not necessary for research on giant clams (National University of Singapore Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee).

Five individuals (controls; n = 5) were sampled directly and randomly from all the three glass tanks, and killed for tissue sampling after 12 h of darkness in the normal 12 h light:12 h dark regime. Other individuals were then exposed to light for 3, 6 or 12 h. At each specific time points, five individuals (n = 5) were randomly selected and killed for tissue sampling. Individual clams were anaesthetized with 0.2% phenoxyethanol before being forced open to cut the adductor muscles.
Collected tissue samples were stored at -80 • C until analyses.

Separately, three individuals exposed to darkness for 12 h (n = 3) and three individuals exposed to light for 12 h (n = 3) were anaesthetized in 0.2% phenoxyethanol and killed for the sampling of tissues for immunofluorescence microscopy. Samples were immersion-fixed in 3% paraformaldehyde in seawater at 4 • C overnight and processed according to the method of Hiong et al. (2017a).

div.head: Extraction of total RNA and synthesis of cDNA
div.p: The total RNA from tissue samples was isolated using TRI Reagent™ (Sigma-Aldrich Co. St. Louis, MO, USA). Samples were homogenized with silica beads (425-600 μm; Sigma-Aldrich) in TRI Reagent® using a Mini-G™ tissue homogenizer (SPEX® Sample Prep, Metuchen, NJ, USA). Remnant of DNA was removed by PureLink™ RNA Mini Kit (Invitrogen, Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., Waltham, MA, USA), and the purified RNA was quantified by a Shimadzu BioSpec-nano spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Corporation, Tokyo, Japan). After verification of the integrity of RNA by electrophoresis, cDNA was synthesized from the purified total RNA using the RevertAid™ first-strand cDNA synthesis kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc.).

div.head: PCR, cloning, rapid amplification of cDNA ends (RACE)-PCR and sequencing
div.p: The partial NCX1-like sequence was isolated using PCR primers (Forward:

5'-TGGGATCTGCTGCTTTCAA-3 ′ and Reverse: 5'-CTGCTCACCATACCATTGAAT-3 ′ ) designed from the homologous regions of Lingula anatina NCX1-like (XM_013531431.2), Mizuhopecten yessoensis NCX1-like (XM_021503412.1), and Cherax destructor NCX1 (KP299984.1). A 9902 Veriti 96-well thermal cycle (Thermo Fisher Scientific) and DreamTaq™ polymerase (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc.) were used to perform PCR. The PCR thermal cycle included a 3 min of initial denaturation at 95 • C, followed by 40 cycles of denaturation for 30 s at 95 • C, annealing for 30 s at 55 • C and extension for 1 min at 72 • C, and a final extension for 10 min at 72 • C. PCR products were separated using agarose gel electrophoresis. Then, the band-of-interest was excised and purified using Wizard® SV Gel and PCR Clean-up System (Promega, Madison, WI, USA).

Following the method of Chan et al. (2020b), the pGEM-T Easy vector system (Promega Corporation) was used to clone and transform the extracted PCR product into JM109 Escherichia coli competent cells. Multiple clones were sequenced to obtain partial NCX1-like fragments. The sequences were analysed by using BioEdit version 7.2.5. BlastN (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/BLAST) was used to confirm the identity of the sequences obtained. Analysis of multiple sequences revealed the absence of isoforms. Subsequently, the full coding sequence of NCX1-like was obtained by performing 5 ′ and 3' RACE (SMARTer™ RACE cDNA amplification kit: Clontech Laboratories, Mountain View, CA, USA) PCR with specific RACE primers (Forward: 5 ′ -CCTACCTGTTCAAGGA-GAGCTGTGG-3 ′ and Reverse: 5 ′ -ATCGGCAATGTATGCAATGA-CAACCATGGCT-3 ′ ). To prepare samples for sequencing, the BigDye Terminator v3.1 Cycle Sequencing Kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc.) was used in combination with ethanol/sodium acetate precipitation. Sequencing was performed using a 3130XL Genetic Analyzer (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc.). The complete coding cDNA sequence of NCX1-like sequence was deposited into GenBank (accession number MW353260).

div.head: Deduced amino acid sequence and phenogramic analysis
div.p: The nucleotide sequence of NCX1-like was translated into NCX1-like amino acid sequence using the ExPASy Proteomic server (http://web.ex pasy.org/translate/). The TOPCONS protein structure prediction server (Tsirigos et al., 2015; http://topcons.cbr.su.se/) was used to predict the transmembrane regions (TMs) in the deduced amino acid sequence.

Amino acid sequences of NCX isoforms from other animals were obtained from Genbank (Supplementary Table 1). These sequences were then aligned using ClustalX2. Subsequently, the identity of NCX1-like obtained from the ctenidium of T. squamosa was confirmed by performing phenogramic analysis using the neighbor-joining method with 1000 bootstrap replicates in Phylip.

div.head: Quantitative real-time PCR (qPCR)
div.p: cDNA (4 μg) was synthesized from the purified total RNA obtained from the ctenidium of T. squamosa using random hexamer primers and RevertAid™ first strand cDNA synthesis kit. The transcript level of NCX1-like was quantified using a StepOnePlusTM Real-Time PCR System (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc.). The pair of specific qPCR primers (Forward: 5'-GTGTGATTGGTAAACGAGGC-3 ′ ) and Reverse: (5'-GCAC-CATTGACCCGTTGTA − 3 ′ ) was stringently designed so that it would have a low probability in reacting with NCX3-like (Supplementary Table 2). For the absolute quantification of NKAα, the pair of specific qPCR primers (Forward: 5'-GACACAATACAGCTCCATCC-3 ′ ) and Reverse: (5'-CTCACCTTGCCTTCATTCTC -3 ′ ) designed by Boo et al. (2017) were adopted in this study. The overall amplification efficiency for NCX1-like primers and NKAα primers were 95.7% and 97.6%, respectively. Both the transcript levels of NCX1-like and NKAα were calculated using the plasmid standard curves following the methods described in previous publications (Hiong et al., 2017a(Hiong et al., , 2017b).

div.head: Antibodies
div.p: For immunofluorescence microscopy and Western blotting, a rabbit polyclonal anti-NCX1-like antibody was custom-made by GenScript (Piscataway, NJ, U.S.A.) against residues 491-504 (AVAGRDYDESA-GEI) of NCX1-like of T. squamosa. The anti-NKAα antibody (epitope sequence ELKQELTMDEHKIP) used for immunofluorescence microscopy and Western blotting in this study was identical to that described by Boo et al. (2017). The anti-α-tubulin antibody (12G10) was procured from the Developmental Studies Hybridoma Bank.

div.head: Western blotting
div.p: Protein extraction was performed according to the methods of Hiong et al. (2017b). For the immunoblotting of NCX1-like, 100 μg of ctenidial protein was separated electrophoretically by 8% SDS-PAGE and then trans-blotted onto nitrocellulose membrane. The blot was incubated with anti-NCX1-like (1.25 μg ml − 1 ) or anti-α-tubulin (0.05 μg ml − 1 ) antibodies in Fast Western Antibody Diluent (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc.) for 1 h at 25 • C. Then the blot was incubated for 15 min at 25 • C with the secondary antibody provided in the kit. The subsequent steps were performed according to the methods described in Chan et al. (2020b). As the custom-made anti-NCX1-like antibody is a polyclonal antibody, multiple bands were observed. The molecular masses of the immunolabelled bands were estimated by comparison with the West-ernSure(R) Pre-stained Chemiluminescent Protein Ladder (LI-COR, USA). The band of interest was estimated based on the molecular mass of 80-90 kDa as predicted by the translated amino acid sequence of NCX1like. Importantly, a peptide competition assay (PCA) was performed by incubating the anti-NCX1-like antibody with the corresponding immunizing peptide provided by Genscript at a ratio of 1:5 for 1 h prior to immunostaining in order to confirm the identity of the band of interest.

For NKAα, 20 μg of ctenidial proteins were separated by 8% SDS-PAGE and then trans-blotted onto nitrocellulose membrane. The blots were blocked with Fast Blocking Reagent (Thermo Fisher Scientific) for 10 mins prior to incubating with anti-NKAα antibody (0.83 μg ml − 1 ) or anti-α-tubulin (12G10, 0.1 μg ml − 1 ) antibodies in 1xTTBS for 1 h at 25 • C. Subsequently, the membranes were incubated with a secondary antibody conjugated with alkaline phosphatase (Santa Cruz Biotechnology Inc.; 0.1 μg ml − 1 ) in TTBS for another 1 h at 25 • C. Then, a BCIP/ NBT Substrate Kit (Thermo Fisher Inc.) was used to visualize NKAα proteins. Subsequent steps were performed according to the methods presented in Boo et al. (2017). A peptide competition assay (PCA) was performed by incubating the anti-NKAα antibody with the corresponding immunizing peptide provided by Genscript at a ratio of 1:5 for 1 h prior to immunostaining in order to confirm the identity of the band of interest. div.head: Immunofluorescence microscopy
div.p: The paraffin-embedded sample of ctenidium was sectioned (3 μm) using a Leitz 1512 rotary microtome (Leica Biosystems, Germany) and collected on slides. The deparaffinized section was heated in solution of 0.05% citraconic anhydride (Nacalai Tesque, Japan), pH 7.4, for 5 min for antigen retrieval. Then, it was incubated for 10 min in 1% sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) solution at room temperature. The section was blocked with 1% BSA in TPBS (0.05% Tween 20 in Phosphate-buffered saline: 10 mmol l − 1 Na 2 HPO 4 , 1.8 mmol l − 1 KH 2 PO 4 , 137 mmol l − 1 NaCl, 2.7 mmol l − 1 KCl, pH 7.4) for min. The blocked section was incubated with the anti-NCX1-like antibody (1 μg ml − 1 ) or the anti-NKAα antibody (1 μg ml − 1 ) for 1 h in a humid chamber. It was then incubated for another 1 h at • C with the Alexa Fluor fluorochrome-coupled goat anti-rabbit gamma globulin (2.5 μg ml − 1 ;

Life Technologies Corporation). The slide was washed again with TPBS, and stained with fluorescing DNA stain, 4 ′ 6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI) to identify the nucleus. Then, it was mounted in Prolong Gold Fig. 1. (continued).

antifade reagent (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc.) for microscopy. PCA was performed by incubating the anti-NCX1-like and anti-NKAα antibodies with the corresponding immunizing peptide provided by Genscript at a ratio of 1:5 for 1 h prior to immunostaining.

Microscopy was performed using an Olympus BX60 epifluorescence microscope (Olympus Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) equipped with a Differential Interference Contrast (DIC) slider (Olympus U-DICT), as well as corresponding filter sets (Olympus U-MWU, U-MWIG and U-MNIBA) and various objectives. DIC images were taken to visualize tissue structure. DAPI staining (in blue) of the nuclei was visualized using the U-MWU filter (emission at 420 nm). NCX1-like or NKAα immunostaining (in green) was visualized using the U-MNIBA band pass filter (emission at 515-550 nm). Digital photos were taken using an Olympus DP73 camera (Olympus Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) fitted to the BX60 microscope. All images were processed using the cellSens Standard v1.15 software (Olympus Corporation). The overlaid of images was performed using Adobe Photoshop CC (Adobe Systems, CA, USA).

div.head: Statistical analysis
div.p: Results were presented as mean ± standard error (S.E.M). IBM SPSS Statistics version 21 software (IBM Corporation, Armonk, NY, USA) was used to perform statistical analysis. Levene's test was used to analyze the homogeneity of variance among the data sets. One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA), followed by either Tukey or Dunnett T3 post-hoc test depending on the homogeneity of variance of the data set, was used to evaluate the differences among means of multiple data sets. Differences were deemed statistically significant when p < 0.05.

div.head: Results
Nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences of NCX1-like/NCX1like from the ctenidium of T. squamosa
div.p: The cDNA sequence of NCX1-like obtained from the ctenidium of T. squamosa had been deposited into Genbank (MW353260). It comprised 2418 bp, encoding a protein of 806 amino acids with a predicted molecular mass of 88.9 kDa (Fig. 1). The deduced NCX1-like amino acid has 10 predicted TM regions, with an exchanger inhibitory peptide (XIP), which represents an auto-inhibitory region involved in the Na + -dependent inactivation of the exchanger, and two Ca 2+ binding domains (Fig. 1). Additionally, NCX1-like of T. squamosa was closely related to NCX1-like of other mollusks, as revealed by the phenogramic analysis (Fig. 2).

div.head: Immunolocalization of NCX1-like in the ctenidium
div.p: The anti-NCX1-like immunofluorescence was detected mainly in the basolateral membrane of epithelial cells of the filaments (Fig. 3) and the tertiary water channels (Fig. 4) in the ctenidium of T. squamosa. The intensities of immunofluorescence observed for samples obtained from individuals exposed to light for 12 h (filaments, Fig. 3C; tertiary water channels, Fig. 4C) were apparently stronger than those obtained from individuals kept in darkness for 12 h (filament, Fig. 3F; tertiary water channel, Fig. 4F). Reproducible results were obtained from three biological replicates (n = 3) for each condition.

div.head: Effects of light on the transcript level and protein abundance of NCX1-like/NCX1-like in the ctenidium
div.p: The transcript levels of NCX1-like in the ctenidia of individuals of T. squamosa exposed to light for 6 h were significantly higher (by 1.5fold) than those of the control kept in darkness for 12 h. (Fig. 5). Furthermore, exposure of individuals to light for 6 h or 12 h resulted in a significant increase in the protein abundance of NCX1-like in the ctenidium as compared with the control kept in darkness (Fig. 6). Although multiple bands were observed due to the polyclonal nature of the custom-made anti-NCX1-like antibody, the NCX1-like band was identified by both molecular mass and PCA. The application of peptideneutralized anti-NCX1 antibody to Western blotting abolished the band of interest positioned between 80 and 90 kDa (Fig. 6). Furthermore, results from immunofluorescence microscopy of NCX1-like (Figs. 3, 4) could possibly corroborate with the results obtained through Western blotting.

div.head: Immunolocalization of NKAα in the ctenidium
div.p: Anti-NKAα immunofluorescence labeling was observed mainly in the basolateral membrane of epithelial cells of filaments ( Fig. 7) and water channels (Fig. 8) in the ctenidium of T. squamosa. The anti-NKAα immunofluorescence of samples obtained from individuals exposed to light for 12 h (filaments, Fig. 7C; tertiary water channels, Fig. 8C) was apparently stronger than that obtained from individuals kept in darkness for 12 h (filament, Fig. 7F; tertiary water channel, Fig. 8F). Reproducible results were obtained from three biological replicates (n = 3) for each condition.

div.head: Effects of light on the transcript level and protein abundance of NKAα/NKAα from ctenidium
div.p: The transcript levels of NKAα in the ctenidia of individuals of T. squamosa exposed to light for 6 h were significantly higher (by 1.5fold) than those of the control kept in darkness for 12 h. (Fig. 9). Furthermore, exposure of individuals to light for 6 h or 12 h resulted in significantly higher protein abundance of NCX1-like in the ctenidium as compared with the control kept in darkness (Fig. 10).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In aquatic crustaceans, the efficient uptake of Ca 2+ from the medium through the gills is essential for re-calcifying the exoskeleton during the postmolt period (See Ahearn et al., 2004 for review). Using the basolateral membrane fraction (membrane vesicles) isolated from the posterior gills of shore crabs (Carcinus maenas), it has been demonstrated that significantly more Ca 2+ is accumulated in the K + -loaded vesicles as compared to that in Na + -loaded vesicles, suggesting the presence a Na +gradient-driven Ca 2+ extrusion mechanism (Flik et al., 1994). In addition, the activity of NKA increases significantly in the gills of blue crab (Callinectes sapidus) during postmolt period (Towle and Mangum, 1985). Taken together, it can be deduced that the gill epithelial cells of aquatic crustaceans consist of a basolateral NCX, which employs the energy derived from the Na + gradient established by NKA to support the active extrusion of the Ca 2+ absorbed from the external medium into the hemolymph (Flik et al., 1994). However, the identity and the subcellular (possibly basolateral) localization of the NCX isoform involved in the extrusion process in the gills of aquatic crustaceans have not been confirmed.

Light-enhanced shell formation in giant clams naturally requires an augmentation of Ca 2+ absorption from the ambient seawater during illumination. In T. squamosa, the ctenidial epithelial cells can absorb exogenous Ca 2+ through the apical VGCC (Cao-Pham et al., 2019) and the absorbed Ca 2+ can be transported into the endoplasmic reticulum by SERCA-like and shuttled across the cell interior without disrupting the low cytosolic [Ca 2+ ] (Chan et al., 2020a). Then, Ca 2+ must be actively transported across the basolateral membrane of the ctenidial epithelial cells to the hemolymph to be shuttled to the inner mantle that is involved in shell formation. Here, we report for the first time that the ctenidial epithelial cells of T. squamosa expressed a basolateral NCX1like, of which, the protein expression level was upregulated during light exposure.

div.head: Molecular characterization of NCX1-like from the ctenidium of T. squamosa
div.p: Like other NCXs, the deduced NCX1-like from the ctenidium of T. squamosa consists of 10 predicted TMs with a large cytoplasmic loop that contains several regulatory motifs between the 5 and the 6 TMs. The Ca 2+ binding domain 1 (CBD1) and Ca 2+ binding domain 2 (CBD2) located in this large intracellular loop facilitates the activation of NCX1 by Ca 2+ (Ottolia et al., 2009;John et al., 2011). A XIP domain is present at the N-terminal end of the intracellular loop with inherent Na + inactivation properties (Matsuoka et al., 1997). In addition, NCX1-like obtained from T. squamosa also contains two conserved internal repeat sequences (α1 and α2 repeats). These two internal repeats contribute to the formation of translocation pathway for Ca 2+ , while the α1 repeat loop plays an important role in ion selection. div.head: The basolateral NCX1-like could participate in the extrusion of Ca 2+
div.p: from the ctenidial epithelial cells to the hemolymph NCX1 is known to be localized in the basolateral membrane of several types of epithelial cell (Magyar et al., 2002;See Hoenderop et al., 2005 for a review; Hwang and Perry, 2010;Brini and Carafoli, 2011). In T. squamosa, NCX1-like also had a basolateral localization in the ctenidium, and is therefore positioned to extrude Ca 2+ from the ctenidial epithelial cells into the hemolymph (Fig. 11). Furthermore, the transcript level and protein abundance of NCX1-like/NCX1-like increased significantly in the ctenidium of T. squamosa during illumination, which aligned well with the light-enhanced expression of CACNA1 (Cao-Pham et al., 2019). Taken together, it can be concluded that there is an increase in the capacity of Ca 2+ absorption through the ctenidium of T. squamosa during light exposure to support of light-enhanced shell formation.

div.head: The operation of NCX1-like is supported by NKA in the ctenidium
div.p: As NCX catalyzes the coupling of an efflux of Ca 2+ with an influx of Na + at a ratio of 1:3, the increased operation of NCX1-like in the ctenidium of T. squamosa during light-enhanced transepithelial Ca 2+ absorption would theoretically disrupt the intracellular [Na + ] homeostasis of these epithelial cells. Hence, there must be a concurrent increase in the operation of a transporter, which can actively pump Na + out of the cell. NKA is essential for maintaining the Na + and K + gradients across the plasma membrane of animal cells, and these gradients in turn support the secondary active transport of certain ions/molecules (Blanco and Mercer, 1998). Indeed, the ctenidium of T. squamosa expressed NKAα, which had an amino acid sequence identical to that expressed in the inner mantle (Boo et al., 2017) and a basolateral localization (Fig. 11). Furthermore, illumination led to significant increases in the transcript level and protein abundance of NKAα/NKAα in the ctenidium of T. squamosa. This aligned well with the upregulation of the expression of NCX1-like to achieve light-enhanced transepithelial Ca 2+ absorption. Besides NCX1-like, the Na + gradient generated by NKA can also drive three other Na + -dependent light-enhanced physiological processes that occur in the ctenidial epithelial cells of T. squamosa (Fig. 11). These are (1) the active excretion of H + in exchange for Na + through NHE3-like (Hiong et al., 2017a), (2) the active absorption of glucose or urea through SGLT1-like (Chan et al., 2019), and (3) the active absorption of inorganic phosphate through NPT2a-like (Chan et al., 2020b), which are localized in the apical membrane. In turn, the transmembrane H + gradient generated by NHE3-like across the apical membrane can be used to drive the active uptake of exogenous urea through DUR3 (Chan et al., 2018) and nitrate through SIALIN (Ip et al., 2020) in the ctenidium of T. squamosa.

div.head: Certain NCX isoforms can also participate in biomineralization
div.p: In higher vertebrates, NCX1 has an apical localization in ameloblasts, which deposit the enamel during tooth development (Okumura et al., 2010). Enamel is composed of calcium phosphate, arranged in a crystal structure known as hydroxyapatite. In ameloblasts, both NCX1 and NCX3 are localized in the apical membrane, and they work cooperatively to actively extrude Ca 2+ for enamel formation (Okumura et al., 2010). In osteoblasts that take part in bone formation, NCX3 is facing the mineralizing bone surface and acts as the primary Ca 2+ extrusion mechanism (Stains et al., 2002;Sosnoski and Gay, 2008), whereas NCX1 is only weakly expressed and its subcellular localization could not be identified even by using specific NCX1 antibodies (Stains et al., 2002). In the scleractinian coral, Acropora yongei, a form of NCX (AyNCX A ) has been localized in the intracellular vesicles of calicoblastic cells (Barron et al., 2018). In addition, amorphous CaCO 3 can be found inside coral cells. Hence, skeleton formation in scleractinian corals may involve in the deposition of CaCO 3 inside the calicoblastic cells, instead of the translocation of Ca 2+ from the calicoblastic cells into the subcalicoblastic fluid where calcification occurs (Mass et al., 2017).

In T. squamosa, the inner mantle is in direct contact with the extrapallial fluid where shell formation occurs and it expresses NCX3like in the apical membrane of the shell-facing epithelium (Boo et al., 2019). Therefore, NCX3-like is positioned to actively transport Ca 2+ from these epithelial cells into the extrapallial fluid to increase the [Ca 2+ ] therein. Furthermore, the gene and protein expression levels of NCX3-like are upregulated in the inner mantle of T. squamosa during illumination to support light-enhanced shell formation (Boo et al., 2019).

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Light-enhanced shell formation requires the increased delivery of Ca 2+ to the extrapallial fluid, which involves the apical NCX3-like localized at the shell-facing epithelium of the inner mantle (Boo et al., 2019). As a consequent, there must be an increase in the absorption of exogenous Ca 2+ through the ctenidium, which involves the increased translocation of Ca 2+ from the ctenidial epithelial cells to the hemolymph through their basolateral NCX1-like ( Fig. 11; this study). Taken together, light-enhanced shell formation in T. squamosa requires the cooperation of two NCX isoforms located in two remotely separated organs that are connected through the hemolymph. The operation of these two NCXs requires the support of NKA, the operation of which needs a supply of ATP. Therefore, light-enhanced Ca 2+ absorption through the ctenidium and light-enhanced shell formation that involves the shell-facing epithelium of the inner mantle must be supported ultimately by the symbiotic dinoflagellates located in the colorful outer mantle, which can conduct photosynthesis with enhanced expression level type II Ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase-oxygenase of during illumination (Poo et al., 2020). The release of O 2 and photosynthates by photosynthesizing symbionts in the outer mantle may promote the host's aerobic energy metabolism and augment ATP formation in the ctenidium and the inner mantle to support the operation of the primary pumps like NKA (Boo et al., 2017) and PMCA (Ip et al., 2017). Therefore, efforts should be made in the future to examine the effects of anthropogenic stressors, including elevated ocean temperature and lowered Fig. 11. A proposed scheme on the involvement of a homolog of Na + /Ca 2+ -exchanger 1 (NCX1-like) in the transport of Ca 2+ across the basolateral membrane of the epithelial cells of the ctenidium in Tridacna squamosa. Ca 2+ from seawater could be transported into the epithelial cells of the ctenidium through the apical voltagegated Ca 2+ channel (VGCC; Cao-Pham et al., 2019). Subsequently, the basolateral NCX1-like could participate in the extrusion of Ca 2+ to the hemolymph, and eventually circulated to the inner mantle which is in direct contact with the site of shell formation (extrapallial fluid). As the increased operation of NCX1-like would lead to an increase of Na + influx, the participation of the basolateral Na + /K + -ATPase (NKA) is required to maintain the Na + gradient across the plasma membrane. The expression levels of NCX1-like and NKA (specifically NKAα) can be upregulated by illumination. Besides NCX1-like, the electrochemical gradient of Na + generated by NKA can also drive three other Na + -dependent light-enhanced physiological processes that occur across the apical membrane of the ctenidial epithelial cells. These processes are (1) the active excretion of H + in exchange for Na + through a homolog of Na + /H + exchanger 3 (NHE3; Hiong et al., 2017b), (2) the active absorption of glucose or urea through a homolog of sodium:glucose cotransporter 1 (SGLT1, Chan et al., 2019), and (3) the active absorption of inorganic phosphate through a homolog of sodium-dependent phosphate transport protein 2a (NPT2a; Chan et al., 2020b). seawater pH, not only on symbiotic dinoflagellates but also on the host's mechanisms participating in light-enhanced shell formation, such as NCX1, NCX3, NKA and PMCA.
